div1.p: Clark thanks Hench for attempting to locate information about Susie, the Apache girl who was a domestic servant in Reed's household.

div1.head: Letter from G. Glenwood Clark to Philip Showalter Hench, March 31, 1952
div1.opener:
COLLEGE OF WILLIAM AND MARY
FOUNDED IN 1693
WILLIAMSBURG, VIRGINIA
110 North Boundary Street
Williamsburg, Virginia
March 31, 1952
Dr. P. S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I am sorry to learn from your letter of March 20th
that you contracted flu on your return from Cuba. By this
time I sincerely hope you have recovered full health and are
now happily engaged on the task of completing the two papers
you are scheduled soon to deliver.

Please do not seriously inconvenience yourself in
trying to locate information about Susie, the Apache girl who
was for a time domestic servant in the household of Walter
Reed in the West and during the doctor's residence in army
barracks in Alabama. There is no great hurry about this infor-
mation: I have until March 1953 to complete my manuscript.
I am going to Brazil as Visiting Professor of American Literature
at the University of Brazil, Rio de Janeiro, act year. I do
want to complete my writing before I leave the United States
but there are many months ahead of me yet.

Thank you for your kindness in forwarding copy of
my letter to General Walter L. Reed and Mrs. Blossom Reed. I
shall await with interest any information these two kind per-
sons can give me concerning the Apache girl in question.

Please accept my sincere thanks for your generous
aid in this matter.
